verses.text: Clap your hands, all you peoples; shout to God with a voice of triumph!
verses.comment: This universal call to worship anticipates all nations praising God, hinting at the catholicity (universality) of God's kingdom (see Rev. 7:9). The text emphasizes the communal and liturgical response to God's kingship.

verses.text: For the LORD Most High is awesome, a great King over all the earth.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty is proclaimed here as 'King over all the earth,' prefiguring Christ's kingship and His reign over all creation (see Ps. 95:3).

verses.text: He subdues peoples under us, and nations under our feet.
verses.comment: This verse foreshadows the messianic victory, later fulfilled in Christ who puts all things under His feet (see Ps. 110:1). The imagery of subduing nations is fully realized in the spiritual conquest of the Church.

verses.text: He chooses our heritage for us, the pride of Jacob whom He loves. Selah.
verses.comment: God's choosing of Israel prefigures His election of the Church as His people. The mention of ‘heritage’ echoes the Catholic understanding of being adopted sons through grace and sacramental life.

verses.text: God has gone up with a shout, the LORD with the sound of a trumpet.
verses.comment: This ascent refers both to the Ark’s procession and prophetically to Christ’s Ascension (see Acts 1:9–11; Ps. 68:18). The ‘trumpet’ signals liturgical and heavenly worship, akin to Catholic liturgy.

verses.text: Sing praises to God, sing praises! Sing praises to our King, sing praises!
verses.comment: This repeated call for praise forms the basis for regular liturgical worship, which is central to Catholic and historical Christian practice.

verses.text: For God is the King of all the earth; sing praises with understanding.
verses.comment: Praising God 'with understanding' highlights the need for proper teaching and catechesis, strongly reflected in the Catholic tradition. God’s kingship is over all people, not just Israel.

verses.text: God reigns over the nations; God sits on His holy throne.
verses.comment: The vision of God enthroned points to the heavenly liturgy and Christ’s eternal reign, and is fulfilled in Catholic teachings on Christ the King (see Rev. 11:15).

verses.text: The princes of the peoples gather as the people of the God of Abraham. For the shields of the earth belong to God; He is greatly exalted.
verses.comment: The gathering of nations around the God of Abraham foreshadows the ingathering of the Gentiles into the one, holy, catholic, and apostolic Church (see Isa. 2:2). The ‘shields’ symbolize rulers under God’s authority.
